From this, gradually wisdom is accomplished. Because of the accomplishment of wisdom, all sins are extinguished.
As I said before, the power of the sun can remove all darkness. A person cultivating wisdom is also like this.

Because of your previous causes and conditions of good roots, when you encountered me, Shariputra and others, like that wise doctor who can save from suffering and attain immortality, why do you now abandon the light and enter the darkness?
The novice Rahula said:
World-Honored One!
The wisdom of the buddhas is like the great ocean, while the minds of Rahula and others are like a speck of dust. How can they possibly uphold the wisdom of the TathÄgata?
The Buddha told Rahula:
It is like raindrops, the later ones not catching up with the former ones. Although they do not catch up, they can fill a large vessel.

Cultivating and learning wisdom is also like this. Starting from a small amount, it eventually becomes a large vessel. Having become a large vessel, it is transformed into another vessel. In this way, it gradually fills immeasurable vessels. This is called benefiting oneself and benefiting others. Benefiting oneself and benefiting others is called a great being, like me now.

Rahula and the others, having heard what the Buddha said, their minds opened up and they were enlightened. They no longer had any worries. They said, We will fully uphold and practice as the World-Honored One teaches. We dare not have any doubts.

At that time, in the assembly, there was the crown prince of the king of the country named JÄ«vaka. Hearing the Buddha speak the ten wholesome paths and the causes and effects that are inexhaustible, he knelt for a long time with his palms joined and said to the World-Honored One:
The Buddha once had me uphold the five precepts, but now I want to give them up and receive the ten wholesome dharmas.
Why is that?
Among the five precepts, the precept against alcohol is difficult to uphold, for fear of incurring offenses.
The World-Honored One said:
When you drink alcohol, what is wrong with it?
JÄ«vaka said to the Buddha:
From time to time, the powerful people in the country gather together, bringing wine and food, enjoying each other's company and having fun. There is no harm in that.
Why is that?
When I get wine, I think of the precepts and am not negligent. Therefore, drinking wine does not lead to wrongdoing.
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
JÄ«vaka, you now have wisdom and skillful means;
If people in the world could be like you, what harm would there be in drinking alcohol for the rest of one's life?
One who acts like this would be creating merit and not committing offenses.
There are generally two kinds of people who practice goodness:
The first is contaminated, and the second is uncontaminated.
As for contaminated goodness, one constantly experiences the blissful rewards of humans and gods;
As for uncontaminated goodness, one transcends the suffering of birth and death and attains the reward of nirvana.
If a person drinks alcohol but does not give rise to unwholesome karma or a joyful mind, they do not give rise to afflictions;
Due to the causes and conditions of a wholesome mind, they receive the rewards of wholesome karma.
If a person observes the five precepts, what is the loss?
Drinking alcohol while mindful of the precepts increases one's blessings.
First observing the five precepts, and now receiving the ten wholesome [precepts], the merit is doubly superior to the rewards of the ten wholesome [deeds].
At that time, King Prasenajit said:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said, when the mind is joyful, one does not give rise to unwholesome karma, and this is called contaminated goodness. This is not so.

When people drink alcohol, their minds become joyful. Because of the joyful mind, afflictions do not arise. Because there are no afflictions, they do not engage in harming others. Because they do not harm others, their three karmas are pure. The pure path is precisely uncontaminated karma.
World-Honored One, I remember that in the past, when I was out hunting, I forgot to bring my cook. In the deep mountains, I became hungry and wanted to eat. My attendants replied:
'When we left the palace yesterday, we were not ordered to bring the cook. Therefore, we have no food now.'
When I heard these words, I rode my horse back to the palace and ordered them to find food.
The head cook in the royal kitchen was named Åšukra.
Åšukra said:
'There is no ready food now. It will have to be prepared.'
At that time, I was so hungry that I became angry and confused. I angrily ordered a minister to execute the head cook.
The minister, upon receiving the king's order, immediately discussed it with others, saying:
'In the entire country, only this one person is loyal, honest, and straightforward. If he is killed now, there will be no one else who can serve as the king's cook and satisfy the king's wishes.'
At that time, when Queen MallikÄ heard that King Prasenajit had ordered ÅšyÄmÄka to be killed, she felt great affection for him;
knowing that the king was hungry, she ordered good meat and fine wine to be prepared, bathed herself in fragrant water, adorned her body, and went to where I was, together with her female attendants.

Queen MallikÄ upheld the Buddha's five precepts and did not drink alcohol, and I always resented it.

Today, she suddenly brought wine and meat to enjoy and relax together, and I immediately drank wine and ate meat with the queen, made various kinds of music, and joyfully entertained ourselves, and my angry mind disappeared.
The queen knew that I had forgotten my anger and immediately sent a palace attendant to convey my order, telling the outer ministers not to kill the kitchen supervisor.
He immediately accepted the order.
When I arrived the next morning, I deeply regretted it and was sorrowful and unhappy, with a haggard complexion.
The queen asked me:

I said:
'Yesterday, I was tormented by the fire of hunger and, in a state of anger, killed Åšuka.
I consider that there is no one else in the country who is capable of supervising my kitchen like Åšuka. It is for this reason that I regret and sorrow.'
The queen laughed and said:
'That person is still alive. I wish the king not to worry.'
I asked again:
'Is it really so, or is it a joke?'
She replied:
'It is true, not an empty word.
I ordered my attendants to call the cook. The messenger went to summon him and brought him back in a moment. I was greatly delighted, and my worries and sorrows immediately disappeared.
The king said to the Buddha:

Queen MallikÄ observed the five precepts of the Buddha and practiced the six days of fasting each month. In one day, she violated the precepts of not drinking alcohol and not speaking falsely, and in the eight precepts, she suddenly violated six precepts.
What is the meaning of this?
Are the precepts she violated light or heavy?
The World-Honored One replied:
Violating the precepts in this way brings great merit and no sin.
Why is it so?
It is for the sake of benefiting others.
As I said before, there are generally two kinds of good deeds that a noble person cultivates:
one is wholesome with outflows, and the other is wholesome without outflows.
The precepts that Queen MallikÄ violated fall into the category of wholesome with outflows;
the precepts she did not violate are called wholesome without outflows.
Those who rely on the meaning of the words means that even if one breaks precepts and cultivates goodness, it is called contaminated goodness.
Those who rely on the meaning means that any goodness that arises in the ordinary mind is all uncontaminated karma.
The king said to the Buddha:

As the World-Honored One has said, if Mallika the queen drinks alcohol and breaks the precepts, but does not give rise to an evil mind, she will have merit and no retribution for her offenses, then this is also true for all people.
Why is this?

I recall not long ago in the city of Shravasti, there were some powerful kshatriyas and royal officials who, due to a minor dispute, gave rise to great resentment. They each formed alliances and raised armies to punish each other. Both sides were powerful clans in the country and were also relatives, so it was not appropriate to arrest them. The fighting and battles were not in accordance with principled advice, which caused deep concern.
I also thought to myself:
In the past when I was a prince, there was a minister of the former king named Devadatta. Relying on his family's wealth and power, he was arrogant and made fun of me, even worse than animals.
At that time, I was angry and did not think things through. I wanted to exterminate them, but I was not strong enough.
I complained to my father, the king, but he did not listen.
I harbored poison and resentment, and there was nothing I could do about it.
Because of this, my food and drink decreased as usual, and I was distressed and sorrowful.
At that time, the queen mother saw that I was sorrowful and tried to console me in various ways, but my sorrow did not cease.
Then, the queen mother, out of deep love for her son, sent a messenger to seek good wine and urged me to drink it.
I then said to my mother:
Our ancestors have passed down the practice of serving NÄrÄyaá¹‡a and honoring the brahmins.
If I were to drink alcohol now, I fear the gods' anger and being punished by the brahmins.
The queen mother was afraid that her son would die, so in the quiet of the night she closed the palace gates, not allowing any outsiders, eunuchs, maids, or others to know. The queen mother said:
The celestial spirits have compassionate hearts to save all from suffering. The Brahmins should all be like this.
Your son is now in grief and will lose his life in vain. Can the celestial spirits really save your son's life?
You should take medicine to dispel your worries and save your own life.
The Brahmins have not yet attained the heavenly eye, so how can they know your son's hidden affairs?
He pressed her again and again, and she reluctantly agreed.
After drinking the wine, she forgot her sorrow and grief.

The Empress Dowager saw that her son had regained his complexion, and her heart was filled with joy. She summoned the palace women to sing and play music. For twenty-one days, he enjoyed the pleasures of the five desires, and the resentment he had harbored was thus dispelled.'

Having contemplated this, he immediately ordered a loyal minister to prepare good wine and delicious food, and also sent out a proclamation to the nobles, ministers, and people of the country, ordering them all to assemble to discuss the great affairs of the state and the disputes among the ministers.
Each of the two groups had five hundred followers who were summoned to gather. In the king's palace, they adorned the great music.
The king ordered a loyal minister to prepare a beryl bowl capable of holding three sheng, and filled the jeweled bowls with fine wine.
I first drank a bowl in front of the crowd.
The king said:
Now discussing the great matters of the country, I think there are no different minds sitting in this assembly.
Now each of you should prepare this bowl of sweet dew good medicine, and then discuss matters.
They all said:
Yes, we will obey the king's order.
All ordered the musicians to play great music, and the people who got the wine all heard the music, their minds were joyful, they forgot their grudges, and they were carefree.
The king again held up the bowl and said to the gentlemen:
Gentlemen cultivate virtue, passing it down through the generations, following the sacred teachings, and should not deviate.
Why do you all quarrel over a small matter like this?
If you do not accept, I fear the country's lineage will be lost.
Therefore, I earnestly advise you to put an end to the dispute.
The ministers said:
We respectfully accept the weighty order and dare not disobey.
Because of this, there was peace.
The king said to the Buddha:
The people's disputes did not arise because of alcohol, but because of alcohol they were able to put an end to their angry and disputatious minds and attain peace.
Isn't this the merit of alcohol?
Furthermore, World-Honored One!

Observing the world's poor and lowly people, slaves, servants, and barbarians, whether on festival days or gathering at taverns to drink alcohol, they are joyful and do not need to be taught by others to each dance;
When they have not obtained alcohol, there is none of this.

Therefore, one should know that people, because of drinking alcohol, attain joy. When the mind is joyful, they do not give rise to evil thoughts. Not giving rise to evil thoughts is a good mind. The causes and conditions of a good mind should result in good rewards.
Furthermore, World-Honored One!
Monkeys can still dance when they get wine, let alone worldly people?
As the World-Honored One said, giving good brings good rewards, giving evil brings evil consequences.
Like worldly people, due to the causes and conditions of their past meritorious giving, they now become very wealthy.
The poor beg from them, but they are stingy and do not give. Due to the causes and conditions of their stinginess and greed, they receive the retribution of hungry ghosts.
There are worldly men and women who have perfect bodies. Men who are handsome are loved by women, and women who are beautiful are favored by men.
If there is powerful force that prevents men and women from coming together, because they cannot unite, they will experience suffering and distress.
Where will this misfortune and sin go?
Queen MallikÄ, because in her past life she gave generously to others, she now receives good rewards.
World-Honored One, how can you have people observe the five precepts and practice the six monthly observances?

On the six days of the month, they are not allowed to adorn themselves with incense, flowers, and clothing, nor are they allowed to sing and play music. They are also not allowed to be close to their husbands and indulge in love. What is the use of this? It is in vain and useless. Isn't this suffering?
The Buddha said to the king:
Great King, what you have said is not wrong.
If when Queen MallikÄ was young, I had not ordered her to receive precepts, cultivate wisdom, and practice the Dharma, how could she have the virtues of today?
Because she was able to attain liberation, she also liberated the king's body. To whom should such merit be attributed?
It is because Queen MallikÄ received my teachings and practiced accordingly that she has accomplished wisdom, skillful means, and liberation today.
Furthermore, Great King!

It is like a householder who has an only son. Wishing for him to succeed, when he is young he takes him to a schoolhouse and entrusts him to a teacher to be taught literature, calligraphy, and the etiquette and deportment expected of a gentleman. The rules of the schoolhouse all have prohibitions, scolding, beating, and punishment, restrictions on food and drink, and not being allowed to sleep. Coming and going must not miss the proper time. Those who violate it are punished according to the severity of the offense.

Because the child fears the beating, he concentrates his mind on studying. When he reaches adulthood, he is highly talented and knowledgeable, and there is nothing he does not know. He then uses what he knows to teach others in turn.
Lady MallikÄ's observance of the precepts and upholding of the precepts is also like this.
Furthermore, great king!
It is like PÅ«rá¹‡a, who, due to jealousy, cut off his ties of affection, took leave of his parents, abandoned his wife and children, and entered the mountains to study.
Wearing clothes of grass, enduring the cold and hardship, he made a vow, saying:
'I must recite and understand all ninety-six kinds of scriptures, treatises, and commentaries, otherwise I will not return to see my parents.'
After twenty years, he mastered everything and returned to RÄjagá¹›ha. He carried a torch on his head, wrapped his belly with copper, walked in the streets, and proclaimed:
'I am omniscient.
' He came to where I was and said to me:
'Gautama Åšramaá¹‡a, what do you know?'
I said to the fool, and spoke a verse:
'If one has heard much but is arrogant and haughty,
It is like a blind person holding a candle, illuminating others but not oneself.'

When PÅ«rá¹‡a heard these words, he suddenly realized and awakened. He put down the torch, untied his belly, and prostrated with his whole body to the ground, repenting in shame. It was all because of his sharp faculties of wisdom and learning.
In a short while, he severed the defilements of the three realms and attained the path of arhatship, with the power of wisdom.
It is like a well-trained elephant that turns according to the hook.

Great King, you should know that those who study all do so by restraining the five sense faculties, and then they can penetrate through without obstruction. This is called unobstructed cognition, and unobstructed cognition means possessing the four kinds of eloquence.
Now PÅ«rá¹‡a possesses the four kinds of eloquence, all of which are attained through diligent study and practice.
Therefore, I say that those with wisdom and understanding have seven virtues and talents.
What are the seven?

First, the talent of faith, second, the talent of diligence, third, the talent of precepts, fourth, the talent of shame and remorse, fifth, the talent of learning, sixth, the talent of renunciation, and seventh, the talent of concentration and wisdom;
These are the seven talents.
Queen MallikÄ possesses these seven talents.

Great King, you should know that although Queen MallikÄ is a woman, her lofty talents and vast wisdom are not the same as ordinary people. This is all due to being careful with her body, speech, and mind since she was young, and single-mindedly practicing and cultivating wisdom.
Because of the power of wisdom, it is called liberation, and with wisdom one enlightens the world.
At that time, the World-Honored One, using the novice monk RÄhula, spoke a verse to the great assembly, saying:
Hearing is like a golden-winged bird, with powerful and strong might;
Hearing is like a treasure trove of conduct, benefiting wherever it is;
Hearing is like a great bridge, saving from various sufferings and hardships;
Hearing is like a great ship captain, crossing the sea of birth and death.
Much learning makes the will bright, and with brightness wisdom increases;
With wisdom one extensively understands the meaning, and seeing and hearing one practices the Dharma peacefully.
Much learning can remove worries and can use concentration for joy;
Well understanding the Dharma of immortality, from this one attains nirvÄá¹‡a.
Hearing is knowing the Dharma of the Vinaya, resolving doubts and also seeing the correct;
From hearing one abandons what is not Dharma, practicing and reaching the place of immortality.
The immortals respect and listen to him, and the gods do the same.
Restraining the mind and not being negligent, accumulating learning to achieve sage-like wisdom.
Wisdom can dispel worries and troubles, and also eliminate evil and decline.
If one wishes to seek peace and auspiciousness, one should serve the wise.
The blind gain eyes from this, like finding a lamp in the dark.
Guiding the people of the world, like the bright one leading the blind.
Therefore, one should abandon foolishness, and leave behind arrogance, luxury, and wealth.
Strive to learn and serve the wise, this is called accumulating virtue.
At that time, after the World-Honored One had spoken this verse, he further told the king:

Your present blessings and virtues, intelligence, and extensive righteousness, are all due to your having personally attended wise teachers in past lives, serving them with sincerity, and learning from them.
The causes and conditions and fruits of your past lives have now made you a human king, with wisdom and insight, skillfully guiding and caring for the people, which is rare in the world.
Therefore, I say that prajÃ±Ä wisdom has four meanings.

Therefore, you should know that those who seek the three vehicles should study prajÃ±Ä. If you wish to leave the suffering of the three evil destinies and eight difficulties, and wish to receive the happy rewards of humans and gods, in short, if you seek all blessings and virtues, you should all study and practice wisdom and skillful means.
As I said before, King Ajita diligently studied the power of wisdom. Although he lost his practice and was reborn in the evil destinies, he still remembered his past lives;

Because he remembered his past lives, he reformed his evil ways, cultivated goodness, quickly attained liberation, and inspired the gods to provide offerings and support him. With the power of wisdom, he became the teacher of the gods.
For these reasons, I say that prajÃ±Ä has four meanings.
At that time, King Prasenajit, having heard the Buddha speak of the causes and conditions of the merits and virtues of wisdom and skillful means, was greatly delighted.
Prince Jeta, the wife, the queen mother, the ministers, and the great assembly all understood and each paid homage to the Buddha, then returned to their seats as before.
The king joined his palms and said:
As the Buddha has said, there are generally two kinds of good deeds practiced by worldly people:
1. good deeds with outflows, and 2. good deeds without outflows.
The meanings of 'with outflows' and 'without outflows' converge into one, World-Honored One!
Why do you speak of distinctions?
The Buddha told the king:
People have two types:
1. those with sharp faculties, and 2. those with dull faculties.
For those with dull faculties, I speak of two kinds of good deeds;
for those with sharp faculties, I do not speak of two.
Why is this so?
The myriad sources and springs eventually return to the one ocean.
For those with dull faculties, whose faculties are dark and obstructed, I therefore speak of distinguishing the Dharma.
At that time, Prince Jeta of the country said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
Are there distinctions in the ten wholesome precepts?
Are they of the same meaning?
Is the meaning of the precept against false speech one?
Or many?
If it is of one meaning, it cannot be upheld in the end. If there are distinctions, I wish for the Buddha to explain it.
The Buddha told him:
False speech is of two kinds:
one is grave, the other is light.
What is meant by grave?

If a person who has received the precepts does not cultivate wisdom, is foolish and ignorant, cannot teach and transform, and does not promote the Buddha's teachings, they will be despised by others, will not receive offerings, and will suffer poverty and hardship. For the sake of offerings, they outwardly display diligence while inwardly engaging in evil and impurity, and they teach each other, proclaiming to others:
'The bhiká¹£us practice austerities and diligently attain the realm of meditation.
' Or they say they have seen the Buddha, seen dragons, or seen ghosts.

Moreover, false speech can lead to murder and the destruction of families. There is also false speech that violates agreements and causes others to become angry and resentful. This is called the lesser form of false speech.
Those who engage in such actions are said to violate the precepts and fall into the small hells.
The other kinds of idle chatter, as well as the various private matters that are concealed, whether saying yes when it is no or saying no when it is yes, are not violations of the precepts.
Prince JÄ«vaka, having heard this, immediately accepted the ten wholesome paths of action in front of the Buddha and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
Today, my doubts and regrets have been dispelled, and I have given rise to the mind of supreme perfect enlightenment. May the Buddha bear witness to this.
The Buddha said:
Excellent!
I rejoice greatly. You should know the right time.
The king said to the Buddha:

As the Buddha has said, the sages and saints of the ten directions understand the causes and effects of sentient beings. My father, the former king, served non-Buddhist paths and upheld precepts, abstaining from alcohol, meat, the five pungent roots, onions and garlic, and made offerings to Brahma, the sun, moon, water and fire;
He always practiced giving, seeking the blessings of Brahma Heaven. Every year he used a thousand milk cows to give to Brahmins, totaling four myriads of cows over forty years.
The Brahmins ate their milk, yogurt, fresh butter, clarified butter, and ghee.
With such merits, what heavens did they be reborn in?
I pray that the Buddha will show compassion, explain and teach, so that practitioners may hear and know this.
The Buddha told the king:
The former king's karmic retribution is now in hell.
Why is it so?
He did not encounter a good time, did not meet a good friend, and had no good means. Although he cultivated merits, he could not escape his crimes.
The merit of giving is not lost, and after the completion of the sins, one will receive the blessings.
Great King, you should know that when a person cultivates blessings, it does not combine with sins. Because it does not combine, it is necessary to use skillful means to make the sins disappear.
What are skillful means?
They are called good and virtuous friends.
What are good and virtuous friends?
They are called right view people, who are good and virtuous friends. They always use right teachings to subdue the mind.
What are the right teachings?

They are called contemplating impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and no-self, the twelve links of dependent origination entangling birth and death, cultivating the four noble truths seeing suffering, cutting off the accumulation, realizing cessation, cultivating the path, practicing the six pÄramitÄs, and the four immeasurable minds. This is called using skillful means to subdue the faculties. Because the faculties are subdued, samÄdhi and prajÃ±Ä are accomplished. Because prajÃ±Ä is accomplished, the mind becomes upright. Because the mind is upright, one can give rise to diligence. Because the mind is diligent, one can give rise to caution. When caution is perfected, samÄdhi and prajÃ±Ä become clear.
Because wisdom is clear, one roams through myriad practices, penetrating them without obstruction. Because of unobstructed practice, it is called liberation. A liberated mind is nirvana.
This is called a good and virtuous friend.
Great King, you should know that a bright teacher and good guide are great conditions that should not be taken lightly.
Great King, you have now encountered sages and saints, all due to the causes and conditions of your past karma. Hearing the Dharma and believing it, you are also able to understand it for others.
Therefore, I say that it is difficult to encounter a bright person, and they are not common. Wherever they are born, their relatives and kin are blessed.
Therefore, one should cultivate wisdom.
The king said to the Buddha:
Hearing the World-Honored One's teachings on wisdom and skillful means, I have already understood them.
As the World-Honored One has said, misfortune and blessings are not the same.
What evil karma did my late emperor, the great king, have that he received suffering as retribution?
The Buddha told the king:
The late emperor, the great king, had six kinds of offenses.
What are the six?
First, being arrogant and jealous, without regard for the severity of matters, one immediately raises the whip and inflicts punishment, due to lack of forbearance.
Second, greedily loving precious goods, making decisions unfairly, causing resentment in the world.
Third, indulging in hunting and play, exhausting the people and harming the cherished lives of sentient beings.
Fourth, confining palace women, not allowing them to do as they wish, causing great suffering.
Fifth, being addicted to female beauty, disliking the old and favoring the new, treating them unfairly, causing resentment.
Sixth, fearing Brahmins, secretly eating meat and drinking alcohol with the five pungent scallions and garlic, fearing being scolded, and acting deceitfully.
These are the six things. The causes and conditions of sinful karma lead to rebirth in hell.
The king said to the Buddha:
If it is so, when the Buddha has not yet appeared, the disciples also have such sins. What should be done?
Cultivating the ten wholesome actions, enabling them to be accomplished without obstruction?
The Buddha said to the king:
As I have previously explained, when the sun rises, all darkness is dispelled. Are there any remaining shadows?
The king said:
Even the light of a lamp can dispel darkness, let alone the majestic power of the sun's light.
Now, the king's blessings and virtues, having heard the Buddha's teachings, have accomplished wisdom, which is like the sun's light dispelling all darkness, leaving no remaining sins.
The king said to the Buddha:

The brahmin teachers whom my father served were diligent and wise, practicing austerities in pursuit of blessings, not sparing their lives, sometimes throwing themselves off cliffs, scorching themselves with the five heats, or fasting in search of rebirth in the Brahma Heaven, sometimes piling up firewood to burn themselves alive, sometimes standing on one leg with their mouths open facing the sun, sometimes tying their legs with ropes on high trees and hanging upside down, sometimes lying on thorns or embracing rocks to crush their chests. There were various such austerities.
The merit and blessings of ascetic practices, to what do they lead?
The Buddha replied:
As I have said before, practicing suffering leads to suffering, practicing happiness leads to happiness.
Have you not heard?
The king said:
The World-Honored One has instructed his disciples to uphold the precepts, isn't that suffering?

When a person is hungry and cannot get food right away, afflictions arise, anger swells, they are unaware, and give rise to hatred and kill a shengren. Such things lead to suffering for many generations. Isn't that evil?
The Buddha told the king:
The reason I previously set the time for the midday meal is because the bhiká¹£us have left the path of non-Buddhists and left home to pursue the Way in my teachings.
Previously they practiced austerities and had thoughts of hunger, so I allowed my disciples to eat delicious food. However, they greedily ate too much and indigestion caused various illnesses.
Therefore, the regulation of meals is not for seeking blessings and virtues through the suffering of hunger.
Moreover, as for the regulation of meals, seeing that the bhiká¹£us beg for food without restraint, day or night, and eat without regard to time, they are ridiculed by the non-Buddhists who say:
Gautama Åšramaá¹‡a claims to be refined in the Way, yet how is it that he is not like the non-Buddhist methods?
Therefore, the regulation of meals is not for seeking blessings through the suffering of hunger.
To put it simply, the precepts that are established are precisely for the ignorant who lack skillful wisdom, not for the wise who know the appropriate time.
As I have said before, prajÃ±Ä wisdom is precisely liberation, accepted by the wise and practiced by the sages.
Having heard this, the king became even more joyful and rose to respectfully bow to the Buddha;
all the great assembly did likewise.
King Prasenajit knelt for a long time with palms joined and addressed the World-Honored One, saying:
Now, this great assembly, having heard what the Buddha has said, has had its web of doubts unraveled, just as sunlight dispels darkness, and has attained great illumination.
Such merit is difficult to repay.
What means do the disciples have to make offerings and repay the World-Honored One's profound kindness in this world?
The Buddha said to the king:
The merit of the nectar-like Dharma teaching is difficult to repay.

Suppose someone were to serve the Buddha, the Dharma, and the Saá¹…gha with all their heart for eons equal to the sands of the Ganges River, providing them with clothing, food, bedding, and medicine for illnesses.
What do you think, would their merit be great or not?
The king said:
It would be extremely great and immeasurable.
The Buddha said to the king:
The nectar-like Dharma is subtle and difficult to measure. It benefits all without distinction, and cannot be repaid by the blessings and virtues of gods or humans.
There is only one thing that can repay the Buddha's kindness.
What is that one thing?
